name: Natalia Lafourcade
description:
'''María Natalia Lafourcade Silva''' ({{IPA|es|maˈɾi.a naˈtalja lafuɾˈkade ˈsilba}}; born 26 February 1984) is a Mexican singer and songwriter. Her music combines elements of [[pop rock]], [[jazz]], and [[Folk music|folk]], characterized by poetic lyrics and her distinctive [[lyric soprano]] voice. She is regarded as one of the most influential [[Latin music]] artists of the 21st century. In 2025, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' named her one of the best female Latin pop artists of all time.

At age 14, Lafourcade briefly joined Twist, a short-lived girl group that disbanded in 1999. She later pursued a solo career, recording several demos before releasing her self-titled debut album, [[Natalia Lafourcade (album)|''Natalia Lafourcade'']] (2002). The album and its breakthrough single, "En el 2000", brought her widespread recognition. Her follow-up record, ''[[Casa (Natalia y La Forquetina album)|Casa]]'' (2005), credited as Natalia y La Forquetina, reflected [[alternative rock]] influences. After a brief hiatus from performing, Lafourcade returned with the pop-oriented ''[[Hu Hu Hu]]'' (2009), which included the single "Ella es Bonita". She experimented toward traditional music with ''[[Mujer Divina – Homenaje a Agustín Lara]]'' (2012), a tribute album to the [[Agustín Lara|renowned Mexican composer]]. Her fifth studio album, ''[[Hasta la Raíz]]'' (2015), earned critical acclaim and commercial success, particularly for its [[Hasta la Raíz (song)|title track]] and the single "[[Nunca Es Suficiente]]".

Lafourcade further explored folk and [[Regional styles of Mexican music|regional sounds]] in the ''Musas'' duology—''[[Musas, Vol. 1|Vol. 1]]'' (2017) and ''[[Musas, Vol. 2|Vol. 2]]'' (2018)—and later celebrated [[bolero]] and [[son jarocho]] with ''[[Un Canto por México, Vol. 1]]'' (2020) and ''[[Un Canto por México, Vol. 2|Vol. 2]]'' (2021). She incorporated elements of [[Latin jazz]] on ''[[De Todas las Flores]]'' (2022) and continued that exploration with ''Cancionera'' (2025). Her accolades include the most [[Latin Grammy Awards]] for a female artist, with 20, four [[Grammy Awards]], a [[Billboard Latin Music Awards|''Billboard'' Latin Music Award]], and three [[MTV Video Music Awards Latin America]].
